document.docAuthor: Matsuyama, Kei & Titschack, Jürgen & Baum, Daniel & Freiwald, André
document.docTitle: Two new species of erect Bryozoa (Gymnolaemata: Cheilostomata) and the application of non-destructive imaging methods for quantitative taxonomy

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Two new species of erect Bryozoa (Gymnolaemata: Cheilostomata) and the application of non-destructive imaging methods for quantitative taxonomy

paragraph.emphasis: Two new species of erect Bryozoa (Gymnolaemata: Cheilostomata ) and
the application of non-destructive imaging methods for quantitative taxonomy

subSection.paragraph:
KEI MATSUYAMA
1
, JÜRGEN TITSCHACK1,2, DANIEL BAUM 3 & ANDRÉ FREIWALD 1
1
Senckenberg am Meer, Abteilung Meeresforschung, Südstrand 40, 26382 Wilhelmshaven, Germany . E-mail: kei.matsuyama@senckenberg.de

paragraph.emphasis: MARUM—Center of Marine Environmental Sciences, University of Bremen, Leobener Straße, 28359 Bremen, Germany
ZIB—Zuse Institute Berlin, Takustraße 7, 14195 Berlin-Dahlem, Germany

subSection.paragraph:
Two new species of cheilostome Bryozoa are described from continental-slope habitats off Mauritania , including canyon and cold-water coral (mound) habitats. Internal structures of both species were visualised and quantified using microcomputed tomographic (micro-CT) methods.
Cellaria bafouri
n. sp.
is characterised by the arrangement of zooids in alternating longitudinal rows, a smooth cryptocyst, and the presence of an ooecial plate with denticles.
Smittina imragueni
n. sp.
exhibits many similarities with
Smittina cervicornis (
Pallas, 1766
)
, but differs especially in the shape and orientation of the suboral avicularium. Observations on
Smittina imragueni
and material labelled as
Smittina cervicornis
suggest that the latter represents a species group, members of which have not yet been discriminated, possibly because of high intracolony variation and marked astogenetic changes in surface morphology. Both new species are known only from the habitats where they were collected, probably reflecting the paucity of bryozoan sampling from this geographic area and depth range. Both species are able to tolerate low oxygen concentration, which is assumed to be compensated by the high nutrient supply off Mauritania . The application of micro-CT for the semiautomatic quantification of zooidal skeletal characters was successfully tested. We were able to automatically distinguish individual zooidal cavities and acquire corresponding morphological datasets. Comparing the obtained results with conventional SEM measurements allowed ascertaining the reliability of this new method. The employment of micro-CT allows the observation and quantification of previously unseen characters that can be used in describing and differentiating species that were previously indistinguishable. Furthermore, this method might help elucidate processes of colony growth and the function of individual zooids during this process.

Key words: Mauritania , Northeast Atlantic, continental margin, micro-CT,
Cellaria
,
Smittina

Records of Bryozoa from waters off Mauritania are scarce. The first comprehensive studies that also included this area were published by Canu & Bassler (1925 , 1928 ), describing bryozoans collected mainly on the Vanneau cruise, together with some minor collections by several researchers and amateur naturalists. Later, d’Hondt ( 1978 ) concluded this short series by describing some remaining Bryozoa collected by the Vanneau . The majority of species described in these publications, however, are from Moroccan waters. Cook (1968 , 1985 ) intensively studied the West African bryozoan fauna, but only occasionally mentioned bryozoans off Mauritania . Records of Bryozoa growing on cold-water corals appear only sporadically in all these publications. This is also the case on a global scale, as bryozoans appear either in faunal lists of the cold-water coral-associated fauna (e.g.
Le Danois 1948
;
Rogers 1999
;
Rosso et al . 2010
), or cold-water corals appear coincidentally as substrata for bryozoans in general taxonomic works (e.g.
Ryland 1963
; Harmelin & d’Hondt 1992 a,b). Notable exceptions are
Zabala et al . ( 1993 )
and
López-Fé ( 2006 )
, who focused entirely on cold-water coral-associated bryozoans.

The present study contributes to a first comprehensive assessment of the upper-bathyal bryozoan fauna from cold-water coral habitats and closely adjacent areas off Mauritania by describing two new cheilostome species from these environments. We also discuss the required environmental conditions and habitat preferences of both species. The identifications and descriptions are based on conventional micrographs from scanning electron microscopy (SEM) that were further substantiated by microcomputed tomography (micro-CT). So far, micro-CT has been used primarily to visualise internal structures of Recent and fossil cheilostomes (
Schmidt 2012
; Koromyslova & Pakhnevich 2014 ), Recent and fossil cyclostomes (Taylor et al . 2008 ; Koromyslova et al . 2014 ), fossil boring ctenostomes (
Viskova & Pakhnevich 2010
), fossil fenestrates (
Wyse Jackson & McKinney 2013
) and fossil trepostomes (
Buttler et al . 2012
), although
Klicpera et al . ( 2013 )
used micro-CT analysis to measure and estimate the ratio of calcitic skeleton to the total volume of a single zooid. The results of our study highlight the capabilities and possibilities offered by micro-CT to visualise and quantify internal skeletal structures. We also tested the reliability of semiautomatic quantification of zooecial characters by comparing them with conventional SEM analyses.

For further examination, taxonomic identification and description, specimens were treated with household bleach comprising 2.8 g /l sodium hypochlorite for 2 hours to remove non-skeletal material, which might increase the complexity of the reconstruction and volumetric rendering of the skeleton. The specimen of
Cellaria bafouri
n. sp.
chosen for micro-CT analysis was additionally cleaned in an ultrasonic bath to remove small sand grains clogging some of the opesiae.

Images of uncoated material were taken using a Tescan VEGA 3 XMU SEM using a BSE-detector in lowvacuum mode ( 20 Pa) at Senckenberg am Meer, Wilhelmshaven, Germany . Conventional measurements, i.e. dimensions of orifices and zooecia, were made on SEM micrographs using ImageJ ver. 1.49 software.

One selected specimen of each species (
SMF 40003
and
SMF 40010
) was scanned with a Skyscan (now Bruker MicroCT) micro-CT for SEM attached to the SEM mentioned above. This instrument uses an X-ray source formed by focusing an electron beam onto a copper target. The X-rays pass through the rotating sample and are detected by a high-resolution X-ray camera. The scanning parameters for both specimens were: source voltage 30 kV, source current 2 mA, rotation step 0.45 ° and 360 ° rotation. These conditions resulted in a resolution of approximately 4 µm. The rotational dataset obtained was reconstructed using NRecon ver. 1.6 . 3.3 (Skyscan) software into 504 horizontally orientated slices, each slice forming a 512 × 512 pixel image.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Charts showing the positions of all stations investigated based on MSM 16-3 multibeam surveys. Stations in bold font are those where either
C . bafouri
n. sp.
or
S . imragueni
n. sp.
occurred. Black areas in the insets A–H denote data gaps. The bathymetry of the overview map is from CleanTOPO2, http://www.shadedrelief.com/cleantopo2/.

TABLE 1. Station data and occurrence of
Cellaria bafouri
n. sp.
and
Smittina imragueni
n. sp.

subSection.paragraph:
The data were processed with the ZIB (Zuse Institute Berlin) edition of Amira software (version 2014.51 ) (
Stalling et al . 2005
; http://amira.zib.de). Zooid cavities were segmented by the ambient occlusion algorithm (Baum & Titschack in prep.), which allowed separation of bryozoan pore space from the surrounding sample space (both consisting of air). Single-zooid and avicularian chamber segmentation, as well as the segmentation of opesiae and rhizoidal pores, were subsequently performed with the SegmentationEditor module. Size determinations were obtained with the ShapeAnalysis module. For each segmental entity, we present the maximum extent in the three primary directions, as well as the volume. These values correspond to the proximal-distal length, ventral-dorsal depth and lateral width of an autozooidal chamber, in decreasing order. For the avicularian chamber of
Smittina imragueni
n. sp.
and the opesiae of
Cellaria bafouri
n. sp.
, the largest value is the lateral width. Finally, the segmentation results were exported as Surfaces and the ShapeAnalysis results were exported as spreadsheets and further processed in Microsoft Excel.

The classification herein follows the working scheme of Cheilostomata by D.P. Gordon (pers. comm. 2014 ) for eventual publication in the revised Treatise on Invertebrate Paleontology . The specimens of the new species described herein are lodged in the bryozoan collections of the Forschungsinstitut und Naturmuseen Senckenberg, Sektion Marine Evertebraten III, Frankfurt am Main, Germany , registered under
SMF 40001
to
SMF 40011
. Some comparative material was examined at the Natural History Museum, Department of Life Sciences, London, UK ( NHMUK ).

subSubSection.paragraph: ( Figs 2 , 3 )

Material examined.
Holotype
:
SMF 40001
, station GeoB 14904 -1, 17° 32.559 ʹ N, 16 ° 39.805 ʹ W, 510 m , Tamxat Mound Complex.
Paratypes
:
SMF 40002
, station GeoB 14911 -1, 17° 28.910 ʹ N, 16 ° 41.509 ʹ W, 450 m , Tamxat Mound Complex;
SMF 40003
, station GeoB 14760 -2, 19° 44.292 ʹ N, 17 °08.754ʹ W, 478 m , Arguin Canyon;
SMF 40004
, station GeoB 14802 -1, 20° 14.791 ʹ N, 17 ° 40.188 ʹ W, 595 m , Tanoudert Canyon.
Etymology. The species name is derived from the Bafour, pre-Islamic inhabitants of what is now Mauritania .

Diagnosis.
Cellaria
with subhexagonal zooids in alternating longitudinal rows, a smooth cryptocyst, two stout, frontally directed oral denticles in proximal corners and a denticulate ooecial plate.

Description. Colony erect, flexible, slender, dichotomously branching. Internodes 4–5 mm long, composed of 10–12 rows of zooids. Joints brownish. Fertile segments slightly thickened. Zooids arranged longitudinally in four alternating series (
Fig. 2
A, B). Each new branch starts with a row of three autozooids (
Fig. 2
C). Autozooids regularly subhexagonal; longitudinally successive zooids do not touch each other, but are separated by neighbouring zooids of next row, which are offset by 45 ° (
Fig. 2
A, B). Distal border rounded, proximal border Vshaped. Borders consist of small ridges with shallow grooves on each side. Fertile zooids in contact with those of offset row and mostly with laterally successive zooid (
Fig. 2
B). Cryptocyst mostly smooth, centrally depressed, flanked by two ridges extending from distolateral zooidal borders to proximolateral borders; proximal and distal parts may be very finely granular, but only in some fertile zooids; ridges slightly converging proximally. Opesia transversely D-shaped, wider than long, proximal margin convex; denticle with acute tip in each proximolateral corner, bent 90 °, directed frontally; distal margin beaded (
Fig. 2
A, C). Operculum chitinous, yellowish. Ooecial opening situated at distal end of zooid, distal margin formed by succeeding zooid, semicircular, proximal margin formed by broadly semicircular plate with denticulate edge (
Fig. 2
B). No avicularia observed. Circular perforations for kenozooidal rhizoids on swollen area immediately proximal to orifice, in groups of 3–5 (
Fig. 2
D, E).

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 2. Measurements (in µm) of
Cellaria bafouri
n. sp.
(holotype, SMF 40001), made from SEM micrographs (N, sample size).

FIGURE 2. SEM micrographs of
Cellaria bafouri
n. sp. A,
infertile segment (paratype SMF 40003). B, fertile autozooid (holotype SMF 40001). C, distal tip of an internode, showing the bases of the joints (SMF 40001). D, internode with distal autozooids having rhizoidal pores (SMF 40003). E, close-up of rhizoidal pores (SMF 40003). Scalebars: A, B, 250 µm; C, E, 100 µm; D, 500 µm.

FIGURE 3. Virtual reconstructions of the internal structure of
Cellaria bafouri
n. sp.
(paratype SMF 40003). A–C, three views from different angles. In B, the branch is bent away from the viewer. D, enlargement of the centrodistal zooid in B. E, the same autozooid as in D, but from a different angle, showing the form of the rhizoidal tubules. Scalebars: A–C, 500 µm; D, E, 200 µm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Micro-CT imaging and quantification. Interior autozooidal chambers have shape of elongate cone, proximal end often vermiform (
Fig. 3
). Autozooids in transverse row not directly connected to each other, but with proximal tip of succeeding zooid in between. Interzooidal connections via longitudinally elongate tubes of variable length, originating distobasally on each side of zooid (
Fig. 3
A–C). Rhizoidal chamber tubular, often trumpet-shaped, each rhizoidal chamber originating directly from its associated autozooid, immediately proximal to orifice; in most cases, basal part directed proximally, with gentle bend at about mid-length directing it to final frontal orientation (
Fig. 3
D, E).

There was no significant difference between the superficial length of a zooid and the length of the zooidal chamber ( p = 0.77 ) ( Tables 2 , 3 ). The arrangement of the individual zooids, not touching the zooids of the preceding row, might allow the zooidal chamber to extend a little further. However, this is only sometimes the case; most zooidal chambers have their proximal end just a little below the level of the orifices of the preceding row, leaving a small area without a cavity, i.e. fully calcified, which corresponds to the lateral contact of the preceding row’s zooids (
Fig. 3
). The automatic detection and measurement of the opesiae and rhizoidal pores did not show very clear results (
Fig. 4
A, B) because of high variability in orifice dimensions, especially those of the proximal row (
Fig. 5
A).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4. Scatter plot showing the width (A) and length (B) of opesial and rhizoidal openings detected and measured from the virtual datamodel (N = 37) for
Cellaria bafouri
n. sp.
The horizontal axis represents an arbitrary numbering of the measured entities by the Amira software.

FIGURE 5. Scatter plot showing the width of opesial (+) and rhizoidal (×) openings sorted by zooid rows (A) and columns (B) (N = 37) for
Cellaria bafouri
n. sp.
The datapoints for opesiae not aligned to innermost or outermost columns, respectively, are those at a position in between.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks.
Cellaria bafouri
n. sp.
exhibits some similarities with
Cellaria harmelini d’Hondt, 1973
, which was recently redescribed by
Berning ( 2013 )
, and its subspecies
Cellaria harmelini tenuis d’Hondt, 1974
, as well as with
Cellaria cookae López
de la Cuadra & García-Gómez, 1996 .
Cellaria bafouri
differs distinctly from
C . harmelini
and
C . harmelini tenuis
in having the plate covering the ooecial opening distally larger and rounded, concealing more than half of the opening, and in having much stouter oral denticles. (Note that
C . harmelini tenuis
differs from
C . harmelini
in the relative length of its internodes and in lacking thickened fertile segments.)
Cellaria bafouri
has a smooth cryptocyst, whereas that in
C . cookae
is granular;
C. cookae
also has denticles only laterally on the ooecial plate. The absence of avicularia in
C. bafouri
might not be diagnostic, as there is the possibility that they occur only very rarely and thus are missed in the present sampling.

Distribution.
Cellaria harmelini
and
C. harmelini tenuis
have been reported from the Bay of Biscay, and the latter also from off Vigo (d’Hondt 1973, 1974; Hayward 1978 ;
Hayward & Ryland 1978
). The former occurs between 180 and 700 m depth (
Berning 2013
) and the latter between 400 and 690 m (d’Hondt 1974 ).
Cellaria cookae
is known from shallow water ( 44–47 m ) off Liberia (López de la Cuadra & García-Gómez 1996 ).
Cellaria bafouri
n. sp.
is so far known only from cold-water coral habitats off Mauritania , where living colonies can be found in the dead coral framework at the base of small patches of living corals. Intact colonies were not present on more-open substrata, e.g. coral rubble, but they were frequently present as small, isolated fragments in box-cored coral-rubble samples.
Cellaria bafouri
was found between 414 and 595 m depth, similar to
C. harmelini
and
C. harmelini tenuis
. The smaller range is surely due to the focus of this particular cruise, and future research might reveal its true bathymetric as well as spatial distribution. It occurred at about half of the stations examined, distributed evenly along the whole latitudinal extent of the area investigated (
Table 1
,
Fig. 1
).

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 3. Measurements of internal zooidal chambers for
Cellaria bafouri
n. sp.
(paratype, SMF 40003), made from the virtual dataset.

TABLE 4. Measurements (in µm) of opesiae (N = 20) and rhizoidal pores (N = 17) for
Cellaria bafouri
n. sp.
(paratype, SMF 40003), made from the virtual dataset.

tr.th: Rhizoidal pore mean ± SD Rhizoidal pore range

bibRefCitation.author: Johnston

subSubSection.paragraph: ( Figs 6 , 7 )

Material examined.
Holotype
:
SMF 40005
, station 14904 -1, 17° 32.559 ʹ N, 16 ° 39.805 ʹ W, 510 m , Tamxat Mound Complex.
Paratypes
:
SMF 40006
, station 14904 -1, 17° 32.559 ʹ N, 16 ° 39.805 ʹ W, 510 m , Tamxat Mound Complex;
SMF 40007
, station 14904 -1, 17° 32.559 ʹ N, 16 ° 39.805 ʹ W, 510 m , Tamxat Mound Complex;
SMF 40008
, station 14904 -1, 17° 32.559 ʹ N, 16 ° 39.805 ʹ W, 510 m , Tamxat Mound Complex;
SMF 40009
, station 14904 -1, 17° 32.559 ʹ N, 16 ° 39.805 ʹ W, 510 m , Tamxat Mound Complex;
SMF 40010
, station GeoB 14911 -1, 17° 28.910 ʹ N, 16 ° 41.509 ʹ W, 450 m , Tamxat Mound Complex.
Smittina cervicornis
: NHMUK 1911.10 . 1.1428 , Adriatic, 34 m ; NHMUK 1887.12 . 9.585 , Cape Verde Islands, 183–274 m ; NHMUK 1944.1 . 8.281 , Cape Verde Islands, 183–219 m ; SMF 9811 , Riou Island, 34 m ;
SMF 40011
, Adriatic,
15 m .
Etymology. The species name is derived from the Imraguen, a tribe of Mauritanian fishermen inhabiting the area around Banc d’Arguin.

Diagnosis. Erect, bilaminar
Smittina
with an oval suboral avicularium on the lyrula within the peristome, orientated longitudinally, almost normal to the direction of growth. Spines absent.

Description. Colony erect, bilaminar, multiserial. Dichotomously branching, internodes flattened (
Fig. 6
A). The laminae of each branch are symmetrical to each other with respect to autozooidal arrangement. Autozooids arranged in diagonal series consisting of four autozooids (
Fig. 7
A). Neighbouring zooids on narrow side of branch are on same level (
Fig. 7
B). Zooids more or less rectangular, distal end rounded, surface convex, boundaries distinct. Sutures in primary calcification straight in cross-sections; serrated in area of secondary calcification (
Fig. 6
B). Septular pores simple. Frontal shield cryptocystidean, evenly porous. Primary orifice elongate-semicircular, deeply immersed, lyrula about half as wide as orifice, truncate. Condyles rounded, directed proximomedially. Oral spines absent (
Fig. 6
C–E). Proximally, but still on lyrula, distinct oval avicularium, nearly normal to direction of growth. Rostrum oval, rounded, proximal border finely serrate, crossbar complete, with bifid ligula (
Fig. 6
C–F). Thick cylindrical peristome develops through secondary calcification, projecting from colony surface, almost concealing primary orifice and in later ontogeny incorporating and almost concealing avicularium. Secondary calcification leads eventually to flattened colony surface, owing to immersion of peristomes and avicularia; peristomial rim forms circular or oval secondary orifice that eventually becomes constricted in middle by ‘pseudocondyles’, separating avicularium from orifice and resulting in keyhole shape (
Fig. 6
F). Zooids early in astogeny form encrusting base (
Fig. 6
G, H); these zooids have lyrula with median ridge, and peristomes sometimes closed by secondary calcification during ontogeny, leading to bulbous appearance (
Fig. 6
H). Ancestrula same shape as autozooids, but smaller and with fewer pores (
Fig. 6
G). Ovicells not observed.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 5. Measurements (in µm) of
Smittina imragueni
n. sp .
(holotype, SMF 40005), made from SEM micrographs; N, sample size.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Micro-CT imaging and quantification. Interior zooidal chamber larger transversely than basal-frontally (
Fig. 7
A, B). Avicularium connected mediofrontally to zooidal chamber, immediately proximal to orifice (
Fig. 7
C, D); avicularian chamber shaped like rugby ball, orientated transversely and perpendicular to rostrum, and tapering laterally around zooidal chamber. Two or three frontal pores arise from avicularian chamber, indistinguishable from other frontal pores originating from autozooidal chamber (
Fig. 7
E). Frontal pores cylindrical (
Fig. 7
C, D).

Orificial and frontal-pore measurements form three clusters (
Figs 7
F, 9 ): a large cluster of 441 data points plots between 20 and 50 µm; a second group of 18 data points between 180 and 240 µm, with a mean of 209 µm; and a third group of 56 data points ranging in size from 50 to 140 µm. This last group is most evident in the length plot (
Fig. 9
A), while in the width plot separation from the second group is less distinct (
Fig. 9
B).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6. SEM micrographs of
Smittina imragueni
n. sp. A,
aspect of colony fragments (right, holotype SMF 40005; left, paratype SMF 40006). B, cross-section through a branch, showing thick secondary calcification and different profiles of zooidal chambers (paratype SMF 40007). C, interior view of primary orifice and suboral avicularium (SMF 40007). D, autozooids showing a relatively early developmental stage of the peristome (SMF 40010). E, secondary orifice with an intermediately developed peristome (SMF 40006). F, immersed secondary orifice late in ontogeny; note the vertical orientation of the avicularium (SMF 40007). G, ancestrular area (paratype SMF 40008). H, transition between encrusting and erect growth (paratype SMF 40009). Scalebars: A, 2 mm; B, G, 500 µm; C, E, 100 µm; D, F, H, 200 Μm.

FIGURE 7. Virtual reconstructions of the internal structure of
Smittina imragueni
n. sp.
(paratype SMF 40010). A, broad side of a branch. B, narrow side of a branch. C, single autozooid with suboral avicularium. D, same as C, without the suboral avicularium. E, a single suboral avicularian chamber; the two frontal protuberances are frontal pores. F, automatically detected orifices and frontal pores. Scalebars: A, B, F, 500 µm; C, D, 250 Μm; E, 50 Μm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Difficulties in species identification arise from intracolony variation owing to increasing calcification during ontogeny. While peristomes and avicularia are easily discernible in younger parts of the colony, they become scarcely discernible in older parts. The zooidal boundaries also become more irregular and partly occluded. These limitations can be overcome by using micro-CT imaging techniques or by viewing distal branch segments in the early ontogenic stage. As the internal basal and lateral walls were not completely resolved during the scan, owing to comparatively low acceleration voltage resulting in only a fragmentary reconstruction, we cannot describe the distribution and shape of communication pores. It is evident from the reconstructed transverse stack that new zooids originate from the median lamina, simultaneously on each side.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 6 . Measurements (in µm) of internal zooidal chambers for
Smittina imragueni
n. sp.
(paratype, 40010), made from the virtual dataset.

TABLE 7. Measurements of avicularian chambers for
Smittina imragueni
n. sp. (paratype, 40010), made from the virtual dataset.

TABLE 8 . Measurements of orifices (N = 18) and frontal pores (N = 485) for
Smittina imragueni
n. sp.
(paratype, 40010), made from the virtual dataset.

FIGURE 8. Scatter plots showing the volume (A), length (B), width (C) and depth (D) of zooidal and avicularian chambers automatically detected and measured on the virtual dataset (N = 16) for
Smittina imragueni
n. sp.
As in Fig. 4, the horizontal axis represents an arbitrary numbering by the software Amira. A separation between zooidal (large values on the left) and avicularian chambers (small values on the right) is clearly visible.

FIGURE 9. Scatter plots showing length (A) and width (B) of orifices and frontal pores automatically detected and measured on the virtual dataset (N = 503) for
Smittina imragueni
, showing a distinction between those two entities, with some datapoints plotting in between (see Discussion). As in Fig. 4, the horizontal axis represents an arbitrary numbering by the software Amira.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks.
Smittina imragueni
n. sp.
closely resembles
S. cervicornis (
Pallas, 1766
)
.
Smittina cervicornis
is one of the bryozoans mentioned earliest in the literature, as references to this species can be traced back to
Imperato ( 1599 )
, who described and figured an erect, laminar, branching species from the Mediterranean as “
Porus cervinus
”. However, confusion exists concerning the actual type , as Pallas’s collection appears to be lost (
Kuklinski & Taylor 2008
) and no lectotype has been designated. Pallas also did not provide any figures.

Smittina imragueni
n. sp.
differs from an Adriatic specimen of
S. cervicornis
(NHM 1911.10.1.1428) in the position of the avicularium. In the Adriatic colony, it is positioned in the same plane as the frontal surface, whereas in
S. imragueni
it extends from the lyrula along the proximal peristomial margin, resulting in a more oblique orientation relative to the direction of colony growth. The distal end of the rostrum is also more acute in the Adriatic specimen. It is noteworthy that this Adriatic specimen, which is part of the Canon Alfred Merle Norman collection, has a type label that is amended by “?part of type material”. A small included note states that it was originally described as “
Porella tubulifera Heller
” and was apparently sent by Camil Heller. Another species from the Adriatic (
SMF 40011
) has the avicularium oriented 35 ° to 45 ° from the direction of zooidal growth, which still appears less oblique than in
S. imragueni
. The avicularium itself also has an acute rostrum. Material from the Adriatic figured by
Hayward & McKinney ( 2002 )
as
Smittina cervicornis
seems to be this species. A western Mediterranean specimen from Riou Island ( SMF 9811 ) has the same more-frontal orientation of the avicularium as the Adriatic specimens, but the shape of the rostrum appears similar to that in
S. imragueni
, though it is even more acute. At present, it is uncertain whether the Riou Island specimen is conspecific with Adriatic
S. cervicornis
. Two other specimens at the NHM, from the Cape Verde Islands, also recorded as
S. cervicornis
, which were originally described as
Porella laevis
var. subcompressa
Busk, 1884
(NHM 1887.12 . 9.585 and NHM 1944.1.8.281), show the same orientation of the avicularium as the Mediterranean species, but differ from
S. imragueni
and
S. cervicornis
in other aspects of zooid morphology and in having differently shaped and also dimorphic suboral avicularia.

Another similar species is the less well-known
Smittina colletti (
Jullien & Calvet, 1903
)
, which differs from
S. imragueni
in the orientation and the relative size of the suboral avicularium and
S. colletti
also has a characteristic median denticle on top of the lyrula. The zooidal sizes given by
Harmelin ( 1969 )
for
S. colletti
are significantly smaller than those for
S. imragueni
.

Strong secondary calcification and intracolony variation complicate identification for these three species, and close attention should be given to the shape and orientation of the suboral avicularium. Further studies might reveal the true identity of
Smittina cervicornis
s.s.

Distribution.
Smittina cervicornis
occurs mainly in the Mediterranean (
Zabala & Maluquer 1988
;
Rosso 2003
), but it has also been reported along the West African coast, from Morocco ( Canu & Bassler 1925 , 1928 ; d’Hondt, 1978 ) to Equatorial Guinea ( Cook 1968 , 1985 ) and the Canaries (
Aristegui & Cruz 1986
). Its northern extent is the coast of Brittany (
Harmelin et al . 1994
). The bathymetric range seems to be from shallow coastal water down to 120 m (
Cook 1968
;
Harmelin et al . 1994
;
Hayward & McKinney 2002
), but
Canu & Bassler ( 1928 )
reported a depth of 400 m in the Bay of Biscay.
Smittina colletti
has also been reported from the Bay of Biscay (
Jullien & Calvet 1903
;
Harmelin 1969
) and the Western Mediterranean (
Gautier 1962
;
Harmelin 1969
), in waters deeper than
100 m .
The short account of the different forms of “
Smittina cervicornis
” given above suggests that this is in fact a species complex, containing at least three species.
Smittina imragueni
n. sp.
is so far known only from cold-water coral and adjacent habitats off Mauritania , at depths of 414 to 600 m , where it forms small, branched colonies attached to the dead coral framework in the basal part of small patches of living and dead colonies of the corals
Lophelia pertusa (
Linnaeus, 1758
)
and
Madrepora oculata (
Linnaeus, 1758
)
. In the area investigated,
S. imragueni
occurred south of
18.5 ° N
and in the Arguin Canyon (
Table 1
;
Fig. 1
).

subSection.paragraph: Micro-CT techniques allow the non-destructive visualisation of internal structures not only in 2 -dimensional slices but also in 3 -dimensional virtual models, under the premise that the material contrast is reasonably high, which is usually met in Recent, non-fossilised specimens. Using virtual models, it is further possible to show or hide different parts, thus enabling visualisation of the deepest internal structures and their relation to each other.

Some researchers have already used micro-CT to investigate the internal structures of bryozoans. While Koromyslova & Pakhnevich ( 2014 ), Koromyslova et al . ( 2014 ) and
Wyse Jackson & McKinney ( 2013 )
used virtual slices similar to traditional thin-sectioning, without making a 3 -dimensional reconstruction,
Schmidt ( 2012 )
used micro-CT to investigate qualitatively the internal structure by 3 -dimensional visualisation.
Viskova & Pakhnevich ( 2010 )
and
Wyse Jackson & McKinney ( 2013 )
additionally made some measurements on virtual sections, and
Klicpera et al . ( 2013 )
employed this technique to assess the weight and volume of a bryozoan skeleton, hence obtaining quantified data from the virtual dataset. Our study took the analysis of quantified micro- CT data a step further by automatically measuring the volume and extent not only of all zooidal chambers, but also of smaller individual structures like suboral avicularia, rhizoidal kenozooids, and even frontal pores.

Using advanced algorithms and a scan with resolution high enough to fully separate the structures of interest, it is possible to automatically and non-destructively acquire and quantify various kinds of morphometric data for every single structure, e.g. a zooidal or avicularian chamber, which would be extremely difficult using conventional methods. We demonstrate the possibility of automatically calculating the size and volume of the zooidal and avicularian chambers, as well as the diameter of rhizoidal tubules. Using any of the measurements in the micro-CT dataset, it was possible to distinguish between zooidal and avicularian chambers in
Smittina imragueni
n. sp.
(
Fig. 8
). Furthermore, we could separate two classes of openings in the frontal shield, viz. orifices and frontal pores (
Fig. 9
), which concurred well with the dimensions observed on SEM micrographs. Differences between the mean values for external zooidal length and the length of the zooidal chamber in
S. imragueni
n. sp.
resulted from the overlapping of the proximal parts of succeeding zooids with the distal part of preceding ones.

A limitation results from a small ratio between the resolution of the CT-scan and the size of the feature under examination, which might lead to incomplete recording or failure of thin and/or fragile skeletal structures, as we encountered in
C. bafouri
n. sp.
In that case, the distinct but not very pronounced size differences between the opesiae and rhizoidal pores, observed with SEM, were not reproduced by the CT appraisal (
Fig. 4
). Another example was the orifice and frontal-pore measurements in
S. imragueni
n. sp.
(
Fig. 7
), for which some data points plotted in an intermediate position between the orifice and frontal pores. These outlying measurements were certainly caused by incompletely resolved orifices and frontal pores. In addition, this species highlights the influence of the quality of the original CT-scan data on subsequent analyses. Owing to the comparatively low acceleration voltage of the SEM, the recording of the inner calcification was too poor for automatic detection of the zooidal chambers, and time-consuming manual correction was necessary. However,
Klicpera et al . ( 2013 )
used the same micro-CT system to describe another Recent cheilostome with satisfying results, highlighting that even smaller CT-systems can achieve results with very high resolution. In that case, however, the membraniporid species investigated was significantly more weakly calcified and smaller in zooid size than the specimens we investigated.

Another aspect to consider is the exact location of measurements. This is exemplified by orifice length in
S. imragueni
n. sp.
, which was significantly smaller in the micro-CT data than in measurements made on SEM micrographs. This was because the micro-CT measurements of the diameter of the orifice were conducted at a shallower position in the skeleton, approximately between the secondary orifice and the most basal part of the lyrula, while the proximal boundary of the true primary orifice is hidden by the lyrula. The micro-CT measurements of the orifices had to be positioned in this way in order to automatically detect all distances at once. Also, the micro-CT measurements of external zooid width were significantly larger than the SEM measurements. This difference was likely caused by some laterally growing tubules of frontal pores, which were included in the automatically measured autozooid width in the CT analysis (
Fig. 7
C, D), as they were regarded by the algorithm as belonging to the main autozooidal chamber. Care thus has to be taken in comparing optical/SEM measurements with those taken by micro-CT.

The micro-CT measurements suggest that for
S. imragueni
n. sp.
the size of the avicularian chamber is positively correlated with the size of the zooidal chamber ( Tables 6 , 7 ), and for
C. bafouri
n. sp.
that the opesiae on the inner side of the bend are slightly smaller than those on the outside (
Fig. 5
B). No correlation was observed between autozooidal and avicularian volumes, which might have resulted from the small sample size ( 8 pairs); apart from this, measurements of different astogenic stages of a colony would be necessary to give a biologically robust answer on how strongly zooid size influences avicularium size. The same holds true for size variation of the opesia in relation to the presence of rhizoids or their position in the bent colony.

When micro-CT becomes more accessible and easier to use, it will be possible to implement such internal morphological characters and their dimensions, which were previously difficult to observe, into species descriptions on a regular basis, and to amend species descriptions based on conventional methods.

Except for station GeoB 14888 - 1 , live
S. imragueni
was absent at the stations with the lowest oxygen concentrations, and at GeoB 14888 - 1 only a few colonies were observed, indicating a higher oxygen sensitivity than for
C. bafouri
. This is certainly the consequence of larger zooid size of
S. imragueni
, but primarily to the closed frontal area, with only some pores allowing gas exchange, compared to the large frontal membrane of
C. bafouri
. Additionally, the secretion of calcium carbonate is impeded in low-oxygen environments (
Rhoads & Morse 1971
), and a possible adaptation might be a more weakly calcified skeleton.
Smittina imragueni
, however, shows strong secondary calcification, indicating that this species is capable of maintaining its level of calcification under low oxygen conditions. However, the absence of
S. imragueni
from habitats with an extremely low oxygen concentration might indicate a higher oxygen demand of this species compared to
C. bafouri
. In conclusion, it appears that both species can tolerate low oxygen conditions to a certain degree if the nutrient supply is reasonably high.

Thanks are due to: the crew and scientists on board the RV Maria S. Merian during cruise MSM 16 / 3 ; Björn Berning for valuable comments and for specimen
SMF 40011
; Joachim Scholz, Mary Spencer Jones and Paul D Taylor for advice and fruitful discussions; Patrick Wyse Jackson for help in bibliographic research; Max Wisshak for assistance during micro-CT scanning, Iris Sampaio for specimen
SMF 40002
; and Rolf Schmidt and an anonymous reviewer for greatly improving the manuscript. KM received funding from the Hessian initiative for the development of scientific and economic excellence ( LOEWE ) at the Biodiversity and Climate Research Centre (BiK-F), Frankfurt, Germany , and was supported by the GLOMAR–Bremen International Graduate School for Marine Sciences.
